Efficient approximations of transcriptional bursting effects on the dynamics of a gene regulatory network

Jochen Kursawe1, Antoine Moneyron2, Tobias Galla3

1 School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of St Andrews, North Haugh, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, United Kingdom

2 Univ Rennes, INRIA, IRMAR UMR 6625, F35000, Rennes, France.

3 Instituto de Física Interdisciplinar y Sistemas Complejos, IFISC (CSIC-UIB), Campus Universitat Illes Balears, E-07122 Palma de Mallorca, Spain

Abstract

Mathematical models of gene regulatory networks are widely used to study cell fate changes and transcriptional regulation. When designing such models, it is important to accurately account for sources of stochasticity. However, doing so can be computationally expensive and analytically untractable, posing limits on the extent of our explorations and on parameter inference. Here, we explore this challenge using the example of a simple auto-negative feedback motif, in which we incorporate stochastic variation due to transcriptional bursting and noise from finite copy numbers. We find that transcriptional bursting may change the qualitative dynamics of the system by inducing oscillations when they would not otherwise be present, or by magnifying existing oscillations. We describe multiple levels of approximation for the model in the form of differential equations, piecewise deterministic processes, and stochastic differential equations. Importantly, we derive how the classical chemical Langevin equation can be extended to include a noise term representing transcriptional bursting. This approximation drastically decreases computation times and allows us to analytically calculate properties of the dynamics, such as their power spectrum. We explore when these approximations break down and provide recommendations for their use. Our analysis illustrates the importance of accounting for transcriptional bursting when simulating gene regulatory network dynamics and provides recommendations to do so with computationally efficient methods.

Keywords

Gene regulatory networks, gene expression oscillations, transcriptional bursting, fast-switching environments, piecewise deterministic pseudo-Markov processes, chemical Langevin equations

1 Introduction

Gene regulatory networks are at the heart of many developmental and physiological processes, and are a key component of cell fate decisions [Davidson, 2010]. The expression of proteins participating in gene regulatory networks, i.e. transcription factors, is inherently dynamic. A fundamental example of dynamic transcription factor expression are gene expression oscillators, such as the circadian clock [Patke et al., 2020, Foster, 2020, Papagiannakis et al., 2017, Kalsbeek and Fliers, 2013], or rapid ultradian oscillators governing the formation of somites [Miao and Pourquié, 2024]. Rapid ultradian gene oscillators also encode information necessary for cell-state transitions, such as the differentiation of neural progenitor cells into neurons or glial cells [Kageyama et al., 2010, Phillips et al., 2016].

It is surprising that dynamic signatures of gene expression, such as oscillations, are correctly established and interpreted when considering the prevalence of stochastic effects [Raj and van Oudenaarden, 2008]. The copy numbers of protein and mRNA molecules in gene regulatory networks are often sufficiently small that simple mathematical approaches based on deterministic rate equations fail to provide even a qualitatively accurate description [Kaern et al., 2005, Schlicht and Winkler, 2008, Barrio et al., 2006, Bratsun et al., 2005]. For small copy numbers the intrinsic stochasticity of transcription and translation processes and of the degradation of protein and mRNA cannot be neglected. This raises the key question whether noise is detrimental to the functioning of gene regulatory processes, or if indeed, stochasticity can be exploited [Eldar and Elowitz, 2010]. An example of the latter is stochastic amplification, in which a stochastic dynamical system may show persistent oscillations in circumstances when its corresponding deterministic system does not [McKane and Newman, 2005, McKane et al., 2007, Galla, 2009].

Gene regulatory networks are subject to other types of stochasticity, beyond copy-number noise. For example, conditions external to the cellular environment may vary in time or cell divisions might be uneven [Baptista and Ribeiro, 2020, Huh and Paulsson, 2011]. One additional source of randomness is transcriptional bursting, describing the phenomenon that mRNA production is discontinous in time and occurs in bursts of transcriptional activity. The size and timing of such bursts varies stochastically [Leyes Porello et al., 2023, Larsson et al., 2019].

Mathematical models are a widely used tool to study and and identify gene regulatory networks [Rand et al., 2021, Chai et al., 2014, Pratapa et al., 2020], and their description through the law of mass action [Ferner and Aronson, 2016, Alon, 2006, Tyson et al., 2003] can easily be extended to account for copy-number noise through the Gillespie stochastic simulation algorithm [Gillespie, 1976] or the chemical Langevin equation [Gillespie, 2000, van Kampen, 1997]. It is an ongoing challenge to understand how gene regulatory networks integrate other types of noise, such as transcriptional bursting, to robustly establish dynamical signatures like oscillations and cell fate transitions.

To mathematically describe experimental observations on transcriptional bursting of a single gene (i.e. not considering responses within a wider gene regulatory networks), the so-called telegraph model has been widely used. In this simplest model of transcriptional bursting, the gene randomly switches between states of active and inactive transcription [Ko, 1991, Munsky et al., 2012]. Considerable effort has been expended to parameterise versions of the telegraph model using experimental data and a recent overview of such approaches is for example available from Luo et al. [Luo et al., 2023]. Typically, the comparison between models and data is performed using steady-state distributions of mRNA copy numbers, which can be predicted from the model and experimentally measured using scRNA-seq data [Luo et al., 2022] or smFISH [Sepúlveda et al., 2016]. In some cases, bursting dynamics are directly observed through live-imaging and used to identify parameters of telegraph models and related motifs [Fu et al., 2022, So et al., 2011, Suter et al., 2011, Li et al., 2018].

In addition to these efforts at the level of a single gene, many studies investigate the effects of transcriptional bursting into wider gene regulatory networks. An example are inference approaches that take regulatory interactions into account when inferring properties of transcriptional bursting[Schuh et al., 2020, Herbach et al., 2017]. Recent work by [Gupta et al., 2022], points out that co-fluctuations between transcription factors and their targets may inform inference, and earlier work by [Zhu et al., 2007] and [Rajala et al., 2010] have discussed in detail how molecular processes of transcriptional as well as translation bursting may be incorporated into stochastic descriptions of gene regulatory networks. These efforts often rely on exact simulations of the stochastic dynamics, which can be computationally costly especially when copy numbers of the involved molecules are large. In addition, exact description of the stochastic processes involved are typically not analytically tractable. These shortcomings limit the potential of stochastic simulations in studying gene regulatory networks.

Here, we investigate the delayed auto-negative feedback motif, in which we incorporate the effects of transcriptional bursting as well as noise due to finite copy numbers. Using the example of this motif, we introduce multiple levels of approximations of gene regulatory dynamics valid in the individual or joint limits of large copy numbers or fast bursting. As part of this effort, we extend the classical Chemical Langevin equation to account for Gaussian effects of transcriptional bursting in gene regulatory networks. We show that stochastic variation due to transcriptional bursting can enable oscillations when they are not otherwise present, or enhance oscillations if they are already present. We analytically determine the power spectrum of the oscillations, and investigate for what system sizes and burst frequencies our approximation become invalid. Our derivations of the extended chemical Langevin equation are provided in general form, and are applicable to any gene regulatory network and many models of transcriptional bursting.

The remainder of the paper is organised as follows. In the model description of section 2 we define the model of the auto-repressive network of a single gene, explicitly including finite copy numbers and transcriptional bursting, as well as transcriptional delay. We demonstrate that our model simplifies to previously published versions of the model in the limit of infinitely fast transcriptional bursting, and discuss the alternative limiting case where copy-number noise is absent. In the results section  3 we first discuss the effect of transcriptional bursting on the system dynamics before presenting our main analytical results. Through a systematic expansion in the inverse noise strength we are able to calculate the Fourier spectra of oscillations induced by copy number noise and/or noise due to bursting. We proceed to test these theoretical predictions against simulations and assess the validity of the various reduced models for different regimes of transcriptional bursting and intensity of copy-number noise. We finally include a discussion in section 4. Further details of the mathematical analysis are collated in the supplementary material.

2 Model description

2.1 Gene regulatory network with negative auto-regulation and transcriptional bursting

We start by introducing a simple model of a transcription factor subject to auto-negative feedback (figure 1). Importantly, this model accounts for transcriptional bursting as well as stochastic variation due to low copy numbers. The model extends previous work [Monk, 2003, Galla, 2009] and includes the effects of transcription, translation, and degradation of mRNA and protein. Motivated by the classical telegraph model of transcription, the promoter of the gene can assume two states, one state in which transcription is active with a constant rate, and one state in which the transcription does not occur. The promoter switches between these two states stochastically, and the rate of switching into the off-state depends on the amount of protein present in the system. This simulates the auto-negative feedback, whereby a high abundance of protein can inhibit transcription.

Mathematically, our model comprises a set of chemical reactions between protein and mRNA molecules, and their interactions with the promoter state. The number of each type of particle is discrete. We write nPsubscript𝑛𝑃n_{P}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the number of protein molecules, and nMsubscript𝑛𝑀n_{M}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the number of mRNA molecules. The concentrations of protein and mRNA are then given by P=np/Ω𝑃subscript𝑛𝑝ΩP=n_{p}/\Omegaitalic_P = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Ω and M=nm/Ω𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚ΩM=n_{m}/\Omegaitalic_M = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Ω, where ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω is the system size, i.e. a measure of its volume [van Kampen, 1997]. This delay is indicated by the double arrow in the reaction system and simulates the time required for transcription and subsequent transport of the mRNA out of the nucleus [Monk, 2003, Lewis, 2003, Alberts, 2002]. The final reaction describes the translation of mRNA into protein, with rate αPsubscript𝛼𝑃\alpha_{P}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The number of reactions of each type that occur in each time interval are either proportional to ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω, nPsubscript𝑛𝑃n_{P}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or nMsubscript𝑛𝑀n_{M}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a consequence, the copy numbers of mRNA and protein particles in the system are proportional to the system size parameter ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω. We can use this parameter to control the strength of copy number noise in our analysis, as stochasticity in the rate of each reaction will decrease with the system size.

The function f𝑓fitalic_f is a decreasing function of the protein concentration P𝑃Pitalic_P, reflecting auto-repression and the degree of non-linearity of the function, i.e. its sensitivity to changes in protein molecule numbers is regulated by the Hill coefficient hℎhitalic_h. These reactions were previously introduced by [Monk, 2003] and they have since then been used widely as a template model for auto-repressive feedback [Barrio et al., 2006, Phillips et al., 2016, Galla, 2009, Goodfellow et al., 2014]. Our model in figure 1 and equation (1) is intentionally designed so that the promoter behaves as in the widely used telegraph model for transcriptional bursting, while also achieving the typically used Hill function (9) for the transcription rate for the case of infinitely fast bursting. This allows us to analyse how the dynamics of the model (10) are modified if transcriptional bursting is taken into account. The description in terms of the Hill function is valid, provided the promoter switches between the ON and OFF states much more quickly than the remaining time scales in the reaction system.

A deterministic description of these dynamics is given by the following rate equations (see also [Monk, 2003, Galla, 2009]) for the concentrations M𝑀Mitalic_M and P𝑃Pitalic_P,

We note the delay term in the first equation. This description does not describe fluctuations due to finite copy numbers or transcriptional bursting, and is formally only valid in the joint limit of Ω→∞→Ω\Omega\to\inftyroman_Ω → ∞ and λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\inftyitalic_λ → ∞.

2.3 Limiting cases distinguish sources of noise in the system: copy-number noise vs. noise due to transcriptional bursting

We can distinguish between two types of randomness in the model in equation (1). The first is copy number noise. By this we mean the intrinsic stochasticity in the protein and mRNA dynamics, described by the last four reactions in (1). This randomness is present even at fixed promoter state σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, and becomes more pronounced when there are only small numbers of molecules in the system. More precisely, the amplitude of intrinsic noise scales as Ω−1/2superscriptΩ12\Omega^{-1/2}roman_Ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for large values of the system-size parameter ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω [van Kampen, 1997, McKane and Newman, 2005, McKane et al., 2007]. This is a consequence of the central limit theorem. Broadly, the mean number of reactions in the system per unit time is proportional to ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω, and the standard deviation of the number of reactions is of order Ω1/2superscriptΩ12\Omega^{1/2}roman_Ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Relative fluctuations therefore scale as Ω−1/2superscriptΩ12\Omega^{-1/2}roman_Ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The second type of noise arises from transcriptional bursting, induced by the random switching between the ON and OFF states in the first two reactions in (1). The promoter dynamics operate on time scales which are set by the burst frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. For increasingly pronounced time-scale separation, i.e., for very fast transcriptional burst frequencies (λ≫1much-greater-than𝜆1\lambda\gg 1italic_λ ≫ 1), the transcriptional bursting effects average out, and thus the effects of transcriptional burstiness diminish. Using again the central limit theorem the relative fluctuations due to transcriptional bursting scale as λ−1/2superscript𝜆12\lambda^{-1/2}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The reactions in equation (1) describe the full model, for general values of ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. This setup therefore captures both copy number noise and noise due to transcriptional bursting.

Having considered the limit λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\rightarrow\inftyitalic_λ → ∞, equation (10), in which only copy-number noise and no bursting noise is present, and the joint limit λ→∞,Ω→∞formulae-sequence→𝜆→Ω\lambda\rightarrow\infty,~{}\Omega\rightarrow\inftyitalic_λ → ∞ , roman_Ω → ∞, equation (11) in which neither noise is present, it remains to cover the limit Ω→∞→Ω\Omega\rightarrow\inftyroman_Ω → ∞, in which bursting noise is present, but copy-number noise is not. In this limit, the dynamics of protein and mRNA may be described by ordinary differential equations. However, for general values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, the promoter dynamics remains stochastic. This leads to a description similar to what is known as a piecewise deterministic Markov process [Davis, 1984, Hufton et al., 2019a]. Specifically, in this limit one has

dd⁢t⁢M⁢(t)𝑑𝑑𝑡𝑀𝑡\displaystyle\frac{d}{dt}M(t)divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG italic_M ( italic_t ) =\displaystyle== αM×σ⁢(t−τ)−μM⁢M⁢(t),subscript𝛼𝑀𝜎𝑡𝜏subscript𝜇𝑀𝑀𝑡\displaystyle\alpha_{M}\times\sigma(t-\tau)-\mu_{M}M(t),italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_σ ( italic_t - italic_τ ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M ( italic_t ) ,

for the dynamics of mRNA and protein. The switching of the promoter state is as before, that is transitions from σ=0𝜎0\sigma=0italic_σ = 0 to σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1italic_σ = 1 occur with the bursting frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, and the promoter switches off (σ=1→σ=0𝜎1→𝜎0\sigma=1\to\sigma=0italic_σ = 1 → italic_σ = 0) at time t𝑡titalic_t with rate λ⁢[P⁢(t)/P0]h𝜆superscriptdelimited-[]𝑃𝑡subscript𝑃0ℎ\lambda[P(t)/P_{0}]^{h}italic_λ [ italic_P ( italic_t ) / italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We refer to equation (12) as the equations for the piece-wise deterministic pseudo-Markov process (PDPMP).

We note the term αM×σ⁢(t−τ)subscript𝛼𝑀𝜎𝑡𝜏\alpha_{M}\times\sigma(t-\tau)italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_σ ( italic_t - italic_τ ) in the first equation in (12). This describes the process mRNA production, subject to transcription delay. Production of mRNA molecules at time t𝑡titalic_t only occurs if the promoter was on the ON state (σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1italic_σ = 1) at time t−τ𝑡𝜏t-\tauitalic_t - italic_τ. If on the other hand σ⁢(t−τ)=0𝜎𝑡𝜏0\sigma(t-\tau)=0italic_σ ( italic_t - italic_τ ) = 0 then no new mRNA molecules enter the system at time t𝑡titalic_t.

The different descriptions of the system are summarised in Table 1.

3 Results

3.1 Oscillatory gene expression can be induced and amplified by transcriptional bursting

Our model (1) extends the widely used model of auto-negative feedback (10) to take transcrptional bursting into account. This allows us to ask how transcriptional bursting may affect the dynamics of the feedback loop. To this end, we simulate the full model (1), including bursting noise and copy-number noise, as well as the limiting cases with only one type of noise (equations (10) and (12)), and no noise (equation (11)). We choose experimentally informed parameter values for μPsubscript𝜇𝑃\mu_{P}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and μMsubscript𝜇𝑀\mu_{M}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as well as the parameters αM,αP,P0subscript𝛼𝑀subscript𝛼𝑃subscript𝑃0\alpha_{M},\alpha_{P},P_{0}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the transcription delay τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ from mouse neural progenitor cells reported in [Manning et al., 2019] and detail our simulation algorithms in supplementary section S2.2. As an initial example, we choose Ω=1Ω1\Omega=1roman_Ω = 1 and burst frequency λ=0.1𝜆0.1\lambda=0.1italic_λ = 0.1/min. Intriguingly, we find that the presence of transcriptional bursting can strongly enhance oscillations in the system (figure 2).

Specifically, we plot in figure 2 the concentration of protein molecules nP/Ωsubscript𝑛𝑃Ωn_{P}/\Omegaitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_Ω as a function of time for each model. The dashed line in each panel of figure 2 is obtained in the absence of either type of noise, i.e., from the deterministic model in equation (11). As seen in the figure, the concentration of protein shows decaying oscillations and settles to a stable fixed point. Thus, without noise there is no persistent oscillatory behaviour for this parameter set.

Considering simulations of the full model, comprising both copy number noise and transcriptional bursting (equation (1)), we find that the time series shows persistent oscillations. Given that these oscillations are absent in the fully deterministic model (dashed line), the oscillatory behaviour must be noise-induced.

Next, we consider the piecewise deterministic model obtained in the limit of infinite copy numbers (equation (12)), i.e. the model in which transcriptional bursting occurs, but copy-number noise is neglected (‘bursting noise only’ in figure 2). We again observe noise-induced oscillatory behaviour with a slightly lower amplitude than in the full model.

Finally, we consider the limit of infinitely fast bursting dynamics and finite copy numbers, as in equation (10), (‘only copy-number noise’ in figure 2). We again observe noise-induced oscillations. As these oscillations represent the result of an amplification of copy-number noise only, they are similar to what was reported in other cases of stochastic amplification [McKane and Newman, 2005, McKane et al., 2007, Galla, 2009, Manning et al., 2019]. Notably, the amplitude of the oscillations in this case is considerably lower than that in the full model or the ‘bursting noise only’ model, illustrating that the presence of transcriptional bursting changes the qualitative dynamics of the system by amplifying these oscillations.

3.2 Variation due to transcriptional bursting can be approximated with stochastic differential equations

Our results in figure 2 indicate the importance of considering transcriptional bursting when investigating the dynamics of gene regulatory networks. Our analysis relied on simulations of the full reaction system in equation (1). These reactions allow us to simulate the system dynamics under the presence of transcriptional bursting and copy-number noise. They can be simulated using the Gillespie stochastic simulation algorithm [Gillespie, 1976, Cai, 2007], and mathematically described using the master equation formalism [van Kampen, 1997], or, on our case, variations of it that account for transcriptional delay [Galla, 2009]. However, master equations are notoriously hard to solve, and for analytical derivations chemical Langevin equations are widely used [Gillespie, 2000, Galla, 2009]. Chemical Langevin equations have the added benefit of requiring orders of magnitude fewer calculations in each simulation than the Gillespie simulation algorithm.

Unfortunately, the chemical Langevin equation cannot readily be applied to systems with switching promoter states. Here, we build on theory developed by [Hufton et al., 2019a] to demonstrate how the chemical Langevin equation formalism can be applied to incorporate Gaussian approximations of transcriptional bursting. This latter approximation will be valid in the limit of large but finite values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ.

To derive an effective stochastic differential equation encompassing both copy number and bursting noise we adapt the procedure first used by Gillespie in [Gillespie, 2000]. More precisely, we discretise time, and then require that the time step is sufficiently small such that reaction rates and burst frequencies remain constant during each step. We simultaneously assume that the time step is large enough such that the number of reactions in each time step follows approximately a Gaussian distribution. These two assumptions can only be simultaneously fulfilled in system with large system sizes ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and large burst frequencies λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. Under these assumptions it is possible to analytically calculate the mean and variance of the Gaussian increments at each timestep, and the definition of a stochastic differential equation emerges. Our derivation is described in full detail in Section S1 of the supplementary material, where we provide formulas relating to model (1) as well as for more general gene regulatory networks.

We obtain the following extended chemical Langevin equations,

Protein production and decay are not dependent on the promoter state, and hence the noise variable ξPsubscript𝜉𝑃\xi_{P}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT originates purely from copy-number noise. Its variance is therefore proportional to 1/Ω1Ω1/\Omega1 / roman_Ω. The last expression in equation (14) indicates that there are no correlations between ξMsubscript𝜉𝑀\xi_{M}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ξPsubscript𝜉𝑃\xi_{P}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is because no reaction in equation (1) changes both the number of protein molecules and that of mRNA molecules.

The extended chemical Langevin equation (3.2) provides a possible approximation of the full model in equation (1). The dynamics of the chemical Langevin equation are dictated by two coupled stochastic differential equations. This is a drastic simplification of the full reaction system, which is described by an extended chemical master equation that accounts for the presence of a delay [Galla, 2009, Brett and Galla, 2014]. Mathematically, this chemical master equation constitutes an infinitely large set of coupled ordinary differential equations [van Kampen, 1997]. Nonetheless, the chemical Langevin equation is non-linear, making it analytically intractable. An analytically tractable equation can be obtained by linearising. This involves one further step of approximation and results in the so-called linear-noise approximation.

Our formulation of the linear-noise approximation applies to parameters for which the deterministic system in equation (11) tends to a stable fixed point (M∗,P∗)superscript𝑀superscript𝑃(M^{*},P^{*})( italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We linearise about this fixed point by writing

A key element of the linear-noise approximation is to replace the second moments of the noise variables in the chemical Langevin equation, equations (14), with the values of these expressions at the deterministic fixed point. This leads to Gaussian white noise variables ζMsubscript𝜁𝑀\zeta_{M}italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ζPsubscript𝜁𝑃\zeta_{P}italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with properties

3.3 Stochastic differential equations accurately describe protein dynamics

As an initial test of this approximation, we plot individual trajectories of full model (equation (1)), the chemical Langevin equation (3.2), and the linear-noise approximation (16) in figure 3A. We choose large values of ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ for this test, as that is the regime for which we expect the approximation to work well. Specifically, we use Ω=100Ω100\Omega=100roman_Ω = 100 and λ=10𝜆10\lambda=10italic_λ = 10. All three models exhibit oscillations, indicating that the chemical Langevin equation can capture the effect of noise-induced cycles. Promisingly, all three trajectories appear to have similar qualitative properties, such as the period and amplitude of the oscillations. The potential benefit of using the chemical Langevin equation becomes immediately obvious when comparing computation times: using our implementation, generating trajectories of the chemical Langevin equation for this parameter combination is 463 times faster than generating trajectories of the full model.

While this visual comparison of trajectories is promising, our next aim must be to evaluate quantitatively how well the two models compare. An ideal measure for this comparison would be one that can characterise the properties of the dynamics visible in figure 3A. Such a measure is available in the form of the Fourier power spectrum of the time series. Fourier analysis is a standard method to decompose a time series (such as those in figure 3A) into contributions from oscillatory signals of varying frequencies. The power spectrum summarises this analysis and captures, for each angular frequency ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω, the square of the amplitude, i.e. the strength, of this contribution. Conveniently, the power spectrum of the linear-noise approximation (16) can be analytically calculated.

We conduct this calculation in the supplementary section S2. We find

For the full model and the chemical Langevin equation, the power spectrum can instead be obtained numerically from many repeated simulation runs.

Comparing the power spectra for all three models for the same parameters as before (i.e. figure 6e from [Manning et al., 2019] and λ=10𝜆10\lambda=10italic_λ = 10, Ω=100Ω100\Omega=100roman_Ω = 100) reveals that all three models have nearly identical spectra (figure 3B), highlighting the accuracy of our approximation and demonstrating that our analytical derivations are valid. Hence, the oscillations of the full model in figure 3 are well described by the analytically obtained power spectrum (20).

3.4 Approximation by stochastic differential equations breaks down for small burst frequencies

Our derivation of the extended chemical Langevin equation (3.2) made the assumption that the burst frequency, λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and the system size, ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω are large. But what exactly does large mean? Or, in other words, at what values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ or ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω will the approximation by stochastic differential equations break down? To answer this question, we next seek to computationally estimate this limit by analysing the standard deviation of time series of protein concentration,

ΣP=⟨P2⟩t−⟨P⟩t2,subscriptΣ𝑃subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑃2𝑡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑃𝑡2\Sigma_{P}=\sqrt{\left\langle{P^{2}}\right\rangle_{t}-\left\langle{P}\right% \rangle_{t}^{2}},roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG ⟨ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⟨ italic_P ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (22)

where ⟨⋯⟩tsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩⋯𝑡\left\langle{\cdots}\right\rangle_{t}⟨ ⋯ ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stands for a time average in the stationary state, i.e. after long waiting times. This quantity is a measure of the amplitude of noise-induced oscillations about a deterministic fixed point. Where the power spectrum is analytically available, the standard deviation can be calculated from the power spectrum SPsubscript𝑆𝑃S_{P}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via the relation

A derivation of this relationship is provided in the supplementary section S2.1. We can use equation (20) to analytically predict ΣPsubscriptΣ𝑃\Sigma_{P}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the linear-noise approximation.

We analyse how the standard deviation of each model, i.e. the full model (1), the chemical Langevin equation (3.2), and the linear-noise approximation (16) depends on the burst frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ for a fixed system size of Ω=100Ω100\Omega=100roman_Ω = 100 (figure 4A). The theory derived within the linear-noise approximation captures the standard deviation ΣPsubscriptΣ𝑃\Sigma_{P}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the full model quantiatively for sufficiently large burst frequencies λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. When bursting is slow on the other hand, significant deviations between the linear-noise approximation and simulations of the full model are observed.

To be able to accurately identify the point of deviation between the models, we define the relative error to the full model

rΣ⁢(λ)=|ΣP⁢(λ)−ΣP,F⁢(λ)|/ΣP,F⁢(λ)subscript𝑟Σ𝜆subscriptΣ𝑃𝜆subscriptΣ𝑃𝐹𝜆subscriptΣ𝑃𝐹𝜆r_{\Sigma}(\lambda)=|\Sigma_{P}(\lambda)-\Sigma_{P,F}(\lambda)|/\Sigma_{P,F}(\lambda)italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_λ ) = | roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_λ ) - roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P , italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_λ ) | / roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P , italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_λ ) (24)

where ΣPsubscriptΣ𝑃\Sigma_{P}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates the standard deviation of the model in question (the chemical Langevin equation (3.2), the linear-noise approximation (16) or the theoretical result using equations (23) and (20)), and ΣP,FsubscriptΣ𝑃𝐹\Sigma_{P,F}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P , italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT refers to the standard deviation of the full model (1).

The linear-noise approximation becomes accurate to at most a 5%percent55\%5 % error in this example roughly when bursts occur at least once per minute (λ≈1⁢m⁢i⁢n−1𝜆1misuperscriptn1\lambda\approx 1{\rm min}^{-1}italic_λ ≈ 1 roman_m roman_i roman_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) (figure 4B). Even for much slower burst frequencies, the approximation produces reasonable ball park estimates for the magnitude of fluctuations (and hence for the amplitude of noise-induced oscillations). The relative error between the linear-noise approximation and the full model remains below one for burst frequencies on a time scale of 1/λ≈100⁢m⁢i⁢n1𝜆100min1/\lambda\approx 100{\rm min}1 / italic_λ ≈ 100 roman_m roman_i roman_n. That is, the linear-noise approximation produces estimates that are within a factor of two of the true standard deviation for burst frequencies with time scales of approximately an hour.

Figure 4A also shows that the standard deviation ΣPsubscriptΣ𝑃\Sigma_{P}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reduces for increased burst frequencies λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. This is because the strength of bursting noise scales as λ−1/2superscript𝜆12\lambda^{-1/2}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (to leading order). Thus, for high values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, the promoter’s ON/OFF dynamics average out. Fluctuations induced by bursting then become less pronounced in the dynamics of the gene regulatory network. We would not expect ΣPsubscriptΣ𝑃\Sigma_{P}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to approach zero in the limit of infinitely fast bursting (λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\inftyitalic_λ → ∞). This is because the effects of intrinsic noise remain in this limit, so we expect oscillations purely induced by copy-number noise, as observed for example in figure 2 for the model with only copy-number noise.

The system-size parameter is held fixed at Ω=100Ω100\Omega=100roman_Ω = 100 in figure 4. For very slow bursting dynamics (small values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ) we then expect bursting noise to be much stronger than copy number noise. Oscillations are then predominantly induced by bursting noise. Within the linear noise approximation, their amplitude can be expected to scale as 1/λ1𝜆1/\sqrt{\lambda}1 / square-root start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG, and the contributions containing 1/Ω1Ω1/\Omega1 / roman_Ω in equations (19) and (20) become irrelevant. This is indeed what we see in figure 4A.

3.5 Suitability of our approximation is application dependent

Our analysis of the breakdown of the approximation in figure 4 assumed that Ω=100Ω100\Omega=100roman_Ω = 100, i.e. we only identified a critical value of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. However, our derivation of the chemical Langevin equation (3.2) required us to assume that both ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ are large. Hence, we would expect the accuracy of the extended chemical Langevin equation to depend on both ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, with the possibility that, for each ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω, different values of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ are required for accuracy of the approximation.

We analyse the joint dependence of the accuracy of the chemical Langevin equation (3.2) on λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω in figure 5, again focussing on our measure of relative error (24). We find that the predictions from the chemical Langevin equation reproduce the standard deviation of protein fluctuations up to an error of at most 5%percent55\%5 % when Ω≳0.3greater-than-or-equivalent-toΩ0.3\Omega\gtrsim 0.3roman_Ω ≳ 0.3 and λ≳0.5⁢min−1greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝜆0.5superscriptmin1\lambda\gtrsim 0.5{\rm min}^{-1}italic_λ ≳ 0.5 roman_min start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (figure 5). In the figure, all other parameters are as in figures 2-4, matching those in [Manning et al., 2019].

While our choice of P0=24201subscript𝑃024201P_{0}=24201italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 24201 together with a value of Ω=1Ω1\Omega=1roman_Ω = 1 is consistent with experiments [Manning et al., 2019], the requirement λ≳0.5⁢min−1greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝜆0.5superscriptmin1\lambda\gtrsim 0.5{\rm min}^{-1}italic_λ ≳ 0.5 roman_min start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT indicates that the bursts would have to occur once every two minutes or faster for the chemical Langevin equation to become accurate to an error of less than 5%percent55\%5 %. That leaves us to ask in which regime experimentally measured value for burst frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ lie. In our model (3.2), λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ represents the rate at which the promoter switches from the OFF to the ON state. This rate varies widely between individual genes, and between organisms. For example, live-imaging in yeast suggested λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ of 1-4/min [Fu et al., 2022], whereas measurements on a range of bacterial genes found 0.3/min [So et al., 2011]. Measurements in the fruit fly Drosophila indicate values of around 0.15/min by [Zoller et al., 2018] and up to 2/min by [Pimmett et al., 2021]. Bursting in mammalian cells is considered to be slower than in other organisms, with values of around 0.01/min reported for a range of genes by [Suter et al., 2011]. Yet, for HIV-1 RNA in HeLa cells, bursting frequencies of up to 0.6/min have been observed [Tantale et al., 2016].

Considering these experimental measurements, we investigate the representative value Ω=1,λ=0.1⁢min−1formulae-sequenceΩ1𝜆0.1superscriptmin1\Omega=1,\lambda=0.1{\rm min}^{-1}roman_Ω = 1 , italic_λ = 0.1 roman_min start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in figure 5. At this parameter combination, protein fluctuations in the extended chemical Langevin model deviate from that in the full model by approximately 37%percent3737\%37 % (figure 5). For larger λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, the approximation becomes more accurate, for smaller λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, the approximation eventually breaks down. This illustrates that the applicability of our method will depend on the biological scenario: in some cases, an approximation using our extended chemical Langevin equation will work well. In other situations it will be more suitable to use a piecewise continuous chemical Langevin equation, i.e. a model following Gillespie’s derivation to approximate copy-number noise [Gillespie, 2000], but simulating promoter switching explicitly, such as in equation (12). For small system sizes ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and small λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, it will be necessary to use the full model, equation (1). This is a workable approach, as stochastic simulations using the Gillespie algorithm will be fast in this scenario.

The breaking point of the approximation in our model is at around λ=0.5𝜆0.5\lambda=0.5italic_λ = 0.5/min. This breaking point may be different for other transcription factor networks: the timescale of fluctuations of gene regulatory networks is typically set by degradation rates [Alon, 2006], and one may expect that the applicability of our Gaussian approximation depends on how the bursting frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ relates to degradation rate of the mRNA that is being produced. For more long-lived mRNAs, such as those involved in the circadian clock, slower bursting frequencies may be permissive in our approximation. In a given application, it will hence be beneficial to test the applicability of the chemical Langevin approximation through comparison to test simulations of the corresponding full, unapproximated model.

The chemical Langevin equation we derived assumes Gaussian increments in mRNA and protein copy number between consecutive time intervals. In cases where the approximation breaks down when the burst frequency λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is low, we expect increments to be non-Gaussian, suggesting that slow transcriptional bursting is an inherently non-Gaussian effect. This is consistent with experimental observations that mRNA distributions can be non-Gaussian and non-Poissonian [Munsky et al., 2012].

4 Summary and discussion

The importance of noise in gene regulatory networks is widely recognised [Raj and van Oudenaarden, 2008, Munsky et al., 2012, Leyes Porello et al., 2023]. Here, we investigated how noise due to transcriptional bursting affects the dynamics of the broadly studied auto-negative feedback motif and found that bursting can induce oscillations when they are not otherwise present, and enhance oscillations that may already be present in the system. We provided computationally efficient approximations of the system dynamics and illustrated the utility of our approximation through analytical derivations of the power spectrum of the observed oscillations. This calculation confirms mathematically that transcriptional bursting alone can induce oscillations, and that transcriptional bursting can enhance the amplitude of oscillations if these are already present due to copy number noise. We investigated the breaking point of our extended chemical Langevin equations and related it to biological measurements of transcriptional burst frequencies.

While we limited our discussion to the auto-negative feedback motif, our derivations of the extended chemical Langevin equation is presented in the supplementary material also for more generic gene regulatory networks, and generic models of transcriptional bursting. For example, in future studies it may be desirable to consider models of promoter busting with more promoter states and/or multiple active alleles [Strasser et al., 2012, Lin and Galla, , Luo et al., 2023]. Our derivation of the extended chemical Langevin equation is applicable to such alternative bursting models.

Our investigation continues a long line of research on the delayed auto-negative feedback motif [Monk, 2003, Lewis, 2003, Momiji and Monk, 2008, Phillips et al., 2016, Barrio et al., 2006, Galla, 2009, Brett and Galla, 2014, Burton et al., 2021, Manning et al., 2019, Alon, 2007]. Among this work, [Momiji and Monk, 2008] pointed out that the model presented in equation (11) is insufficient to explain the full amplitude of biologically observed oscillations, and they hence argued that alterations to the model, such as the consideration of protein dimerisation or periodic forcing, are necessary to alleviate this discrepancy. Our results suggest that instead the presence of transcriptional bursting may be sufficient to explain an increase in oscillation amplitude. We expect the auto-negative feedback motif to remain relevant as auto-repression is abundant in gene regulatory networks, suggesting the existence of yet unknown oscillators [Minchington et al., 2020].

Our work contributes to existing efforts to efficiently simulate the dynamics of gene regulatory networks, such as the methods presented by [Hettich and Gebhardt, 2022]. Simulating chemical Langevin equations is generally much less demanding in terms of computing time than the simulation of the full reaction system from which the CLE is derived. Where our approximation is applicable, this means that equations such as (3.2) are a viable approach to studying the role of transcriptional bursting in natural gene regulatory networks. For example, high-throughput simulations of the chemical Langevin model can be used to infer model parameters from experimental data [Burton et al., 2021, Browning et al., 2020].

When deriving our extended chemical Langevin equation in supplementary section S1, we introduce the promoter states as environmental states in a chemical reaction system. The response of chemical reaction systems to rapidly switching environments in this way was previously derived in [Hufton et al., 2019a, b]. This work also included levels of approximation for large copy numbers or fast environmental switching rates, respectively. In these studies, the authors used a Kramers-Moyal expansion to arrive at an extended chemical Langevin equation. Our analysis expands this previous work by providing an alternative derivation of the extended Chemical Langevin equation in the style of [Gillespie, 2000]. This derivation is advantageous to us over the Kramers-Moyal expansion, as it allows a natural inclusion of delayed terms. Without this inclusion of delayed terms, our discussion of the delayed auto-negative feedback motif would not have been possible.

Our work opens up possibilities in a wider range of areas. Copy number fluctuations are known to generate oscillations not only in gene regulatory circuits but also in other biochemical systems, in models of epidemic spread and in evolutionary game theory [McKane et al., 2007, Alonso et al., 2007, Bladon et al., 2010]. Such stochasticity , sometimes called ‘demographic noise’ in other areas, can also provoke spatial patterns or waves [Biancalani et al., 2010, Karig et al., 2018, Biancalani et al., 2011]. It is conceivable that these phenomena can also be induced by extrinsic noise, or be enhanced by it. Further work is required to investigate this possibility.

In the context of gene regulatory networks, we hope that our discussion of the extended chemical Langevin equation, as well as the accompanying approximations for large or finite burst frequencies or system sizes will facilitate the wider study of gene regulation and cell fate.

Supplementary material to the article ‘Efficient approximations of transcriptional bursting effects on the dynamics of a gene regulatory network


Jochen Kursawe1, Antoine Moneyron2, Tobias Galla3
 

1 School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of St Andrews, North Haugh, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, United Kingdom

2 Inria de l’Université de Rennes, Campus de Beaulieu, 263 Av. Général Leclerc, 35042 Rennes, France

3 Instituto de Física Interdisciplinar y Sistemas Complejos, IFISC (CSIC-UIB), Campus Universitat Illes Balears, E-07122 Palma de Mallorca, Spain

S1 Derivation of a chemical Langevin equation for fast promoter bursting

In this section we derive the chemical Langevin description for a gene regulatory network that takes bursting noise into account. To do so, we extend the classical derivation by Gillespie [Gillespie, 2000]. Our approximation is valid for systems with large but finite copy numbers, and provided that the promoter switches between states on a time scale that is much faster than that of the remaining system. Nonetheless, we do not require infinitely fast promoter bursting. Instead, our approximation captures leading order corrections to the full adiabatic elimination. It also describes fluctuations that arise due to finite copy numbers to leading order.

In our derivation, we consider promoter states as environmental states of a chemical reaction system. These environmental states are defined such that they affect the reaction propensities of the rest of the system. In this supplementary material, we first present the approximation through a chemical Langevin equation for a general reaction model that includes delayed reactions and switching between environmental states. Then, we discuss the case where the environment can stochastically switch between two states, i.e. where the environment represents a telegraph model of transcription. Finally, we discuss the special case of the auto-negative feedback motif described in the main paper.

S1.1 The promoter defines environmental states in a system of chemical reactions

Consider a chemical reaction system with molecules of types i=1,…,S𝑖1…𝑆i=1,\dots,Sitalic_i = 1 , … , italic_S, and with reactions r=1,…,R𝑟1…𝑅r=1,\dots,Ritalic_r = 1 , … , italic_R. We write ni⁢(t)subscript𝑛𝑖𝑡n_{i}(t)italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) for the number of particles of type i𝑖iitalic_i at time t𝑡titalic_t, and thus 𝒏⁢(t)=[n1⁢(t),…,nS⁢(t)]𝒏𝑡subscript𝑛1𝑡…subscript𝑛𝑆𝑡\bm{n}(t)=[n_{1}(t),...,n_{S}(t)]bold_italic_n ( italic_t ) = [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) , … , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ] describes the chemical state of the reaction system at time t𝑡titalic_t. We additionally assume that the system may operate in one of M𝑀Mitalic_M environmental states σ=1,…,M𝜎1…𝑀\sigma=1,\dots,Mitalic_σ = 1 , … , italic_M. The environmental states are defined to affect the reaction propensities, which allows us to model chemical reaction systems that can change their reaction rates and structure under different ‘environmental’ conditions. The environmental states may themselves change in time via deterministic or probabilistic rules. In our specific model in equation (1) of the main manuscript, there are two environmental states, which correspond to the two states that the promoter can assume.

We introduce the notation gr,σsubscript𝑔𝑟𝜎g_{r,\sigma}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the propensity of reaction r𝑟ritalic_r to trigger at time t𝑡titalic_t, given that the environmental state is σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. If the system is in state σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ the probability that reaction r𝑟ritalic_r triggers in the next infinitesimal time element d⁢t𝑑𝑡dtitalic_d italic_t is then gr,σ⁢(t)⁢d⁢tsubscript𝑔𝑟𝜎𝑡𝑑𝑡g_{r,\sigma}(t)dtitalic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) italic_d italic_t. The propensities gr,σ⁢(t)subscript𝑔𝑟𝜎𝑡g_{r,\sigma}(t)italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) only depend on the chemical state of the system, 𝐧⁢(t)𝐧𝑡\mathbf{n}(t)bold_n ( italic_t ), and on the environmental state, σ⁢(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t)italic_σ ( italic_t ), at time t𝑡titalic_t.

The dynamics in a short time interval can then be written as

ni⁢(t+Δ⁢t)=ni⁢(t)+∑rνi,r⁢kr⁢(t)subscript𝑛𝑖𝑡Δ𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖𝑡subscript𝑟subscript𝜈𝑖𝑟subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡n_{i}(t+\Delta t)=n_{i}(t)+\sum_{r}\nu_{i,r}k_{r}(t)italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ) = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) (S1)

where the νi,rsubscript𝜈𝑖𝑟\nu_{i,r}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are stochiometric coefficients (the number of particles of type i𝑖iitalic_i changes by νi,rsubscript𝜈𝑖𝑟\nu_{i,r}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in a reaction of type r𝑟ritalic_r), and where kj⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑗𝑡k_{j}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) is the number of reactions of type r𝑟ritalic_r firing in the time interval from t𝑡titalic_t to t+Δ⁢t𝑡Δ𝑡t+\Delta titalic_t + roman_Δ italic_t.

The kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) in equation (S1) are random variables, and their distribution depends on the reaction propensities. Equation (S1) is an approximation-free statement: if kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) is known, it is true for any combination of chemical and environmental states at all times t𝑡titalic_t. Our aim is to make simplifying assumptions that allow us to approximate this ansatz (S1) using a stochastic differential equation.

To do so, we follow the steps originally proposed by Gillespie [Gillespie, 2000] and assume that Δ⁢tΔ𝑡\Delta troman_Δ italic_t is sufficiently small such that that the σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ-dependent reaction propensities gr,σsubscript𝑔𝑟𝜎g_{r,\sigma}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_σ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are all constant in the time interval from t𝑡titalic_t to t+Δ⁢t𝑡Δ𝑡t+\Delta titalic_t + roman_Δ italic_t for each fixed value of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ. We add to Gillespie’s derivation, by assuming that the propensities by which the environment changes between its M𝑀Mitalic_M states are also constant throughout [t,t+Δ⁢t]𝑡𝑡Δ𝑡[t,t+\Delta t][ italic_t , italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ].

Under these assumptions, the kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) are mixtures of Poisson random variables. In particular, if the system switches between multiple environmental states in the time interval [t,t+Δ⁢t]𝑡𝑡Δ𝑡[t,t+\Delta t][ italic_t , italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ], then within each time period of constant environmental state the number of each reaction in this period is a Poisson random variable. Consequently, for a given trajectory of the environment in [t,t+Δ⁢t]𝑡𝑡Δ𝑡[t,t+\Delta t][ italic_t , italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ], kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) is a sum of independent Poisson random variables, which itself is a Poisson random variable. If the environment can change under probabilistic rules, then kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) will therefore be a mixture of Poisson random variables.

We proceed to make a second assumption inspired by [Gillespie, 2000], namely that Δ⁢tΔ𝑡\Delta troman_Δ italic_t is sufficiently large such that the kr⁢(t)subscript𝑘𝑟𝑡k_{r}(t)italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) are further approximated by Gaussian random variables. This assumption invokes the Central Limit theorem and therefore relies on the previous assumption that the propensities within the chemical reaction system, as well as the propensities of the environment to change, are constant throughout [t,t+Δ⁢t]𝑡𝑡Δ𝑡[t,t+\Delta t][ italic_t , italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ]. Our second assumption further includes that many environmental changes occur in the time interval [t,t+Δ⁢t]𝑡𝑡Δ𝑡[t,t+\Delta t][ italic_t , italic_t + roman_Δ italic_t ].

The next step in our deriviation is to calculate the means and variances of these Gaussian random numbers.

S1.2 Calculation of mean and variance of number of reactions in one time step

S1.5 Chemical Langevin equation for the auto-negative feedback motif with promoter bursting

We now seek to express equation (S16) for our model of an auto-negative feedback loop in the main paper (equation (1)). In this model, there are only two environmental states, ON and OFF. In our system, the product of a transcription rate only enters the system τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ units of time later, which means that this rate of transcription does not affect the mRNA concentration at the current time, but at time t+τ𝑡𝜏t+\tauitalic_t + italic_τ. It is a key advantage of the derivation of the chemical Langevin equation using increments of molecule numbers that this argument can be made. Much more elaborate arguments are necessary in the context of more formal Kramers–Moyal expansions [Brett and Galla, 2014].

S2 Spectra of fluctuations

S2.2 Computational implementation

In this section, we describe how we simulate the models in equations (1), (11), (12), (3.2), and (16).

Full model in equation (1)
The chemical reaction system in equation (1) is simulated using the Gillespie-rejection algorithm reported by [Cai, 2007]. Simulated numbers of mRNA and protein molecules are recorded every minute for plotting and further analysis.

Deterministic model in equation (11)
The deterministic model (11) is solved using a Forward-Euler approximation and a timestep of Δ⁢t=0.01Δ𝑡0.01\Delta t=0.01roman_Δ italic_t = 0.01.

Promoter-noise only model in equation (12)
The piecewise-deterministic Markov process, i.e. the model emerging in the limit of infinite copy numbers (12), is simulated using an adapted Forward-Euler scheme. Specifically, at each timestep starting at time t𝑡titalic_t, the concentration of mRNA and protein are propagated to t+Δ⁢t𝑡Δ𝑡t+\Delta titalic_t + roman_Δ italic_t using the Forward-Euler method according to the promoter state σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ at time t−τ𝑡𝜏t-\tauitalic_t - italic_τ, i.e. Δ⁢tΔ𝑡\Delta troman_Δ italic_t is the time increment used in the Forward-Euler approximation. After propagating the mRNA and Protein concentrations M𝑀Mitalic_M and P𝑃Pitalic_P in this way, the propensity to switch from the current promoter state is calculated. This propensity is g=λ𝑔𝜆g=\lambdaitalic_g = italic_λ if the promoter is currently in the OFF state. Otherwise, it is g=λ⁢(P⁢(t)/P0)n𝑔𝜆superscript𝑃𝑡subscript𝑃0𝑛g=\lambda(P(t)/P_{0})^{n}italic_g = italic_λ ( italic_P ( italic_t ) / italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, a random number Δ⁢trΔsubscript𝑡𝑟\Delta t_{r}roman_Δ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn from an exponential distribution with mean 1/g1𝑔1/g1 / italic_g. If the generated time Δ⁢trΔsubscript𝑡𝑟\Delta t_{r}roman_Δ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is less than the timestep Δ⁢tΔ𝑡\Delta troman_Δ italic_t, then the promoter state at t+Δ⁢t𝑡Δ𝑡t+\Delta titalic_t + roman_Δ italic_t is changed from its current state into the second available promoter state (i.e. from OFF to ON or from ON to OFF). This simulates that the promoter switches to the opposite state with probability 1−e−g⁢Δ⁢t1superscript𝑒𝑔Δ𝑡1-e^{-g\Delta t}1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_g roman_Δ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and remains in the current state with probability e−g⁢Δ⁢tsuperscript𝑒𝑔Δ𝑡e^{-g\Delta t}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_g roman_Δ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This procedure is repeated for the duration T𝑇Titalic_T of the simulation. A timestep of Δ⁢t=0.0001Δ𝑡0.0001\Delta t=0.0001roman_Δ italic_t = 0.0001 is used in our simulations, and values of M𝑀Mitalic_M and P𝑃Pitalic_P at every full minute are recorded for plotting.

Extended chemical Langevin equation in equation (3.2)
The chemical Langevin equation (3.2) is simulated using a delayed Euler–Maruyama scheme. We use reflecting boundary conditions on the copy numbers of the protein and the mRNA at zero copy numbers, i.e. if the predicted number of protein or mRNA is negative at a given timestep, the absolute value of that prediction is used when propagating into the next timestep. A timestep of Δ⁢t=0.01Δ𝑡0.01\Delta t=0.01roman_Δ italic_t = 0.01 is used in the approximation, and values of M𝑀Mitalic_M and P𝑃Pitalic_P at every full minute are recorded for plotting.

Linear-noise approximation in equation (16)
The linear-noise approximation (16) is simulated in the same way as the chemical Langevin equation, except that we do not use a reflecting boundary condition at zero. This difference is necessary to enable comparison between analytical and computational predictions from the linear-noise approximation.

Condition for past times
At past times (t<0𝑡0t<0italic_t < 0), all models except the linear-noise approximation assume M⁢(t)=0𝑀𝑡0M(t)=0italic_M ( italic_t ) = 0 and P⁢(t)=0𝑃𝑡0P(t)=0italic_P ( italic_t ) = 0. This is equivalent to saying that m⁢(t)=p⁢(t)=0𝑚𝑡𝑝𝑡0m(t)=p(t)=0italic_m ( italic_t ) = italic_p ( italic_t ) = 0. Defining values for past times in this way is required to interrogate P⁢(t−τ)𝑃𝑡𝜏P(t-\tau)italic_P ( italic_t - italic_τ ) when t<τ𝑡𝜏t<\tauitalic_t < italic_τ.

Code availability
Each algorithm is implemented in python and the code to simulate each model is available on github under https://github.com/Lord-Fufu/MSc-Dissertation-2022---St-Andrews.
